Modelling in Mujoco's XML format

Published: Mar 8, 2022 â€¢â€¢ Rishabh Goel

Oh hello!ðŸ‘‹

Welcome to this article on modelling in MuJoCo. Hopefully, this article will provide you with a good understanding of modelling in XML format, so that you may create many more complex models of your own.

I will show you by creating a Quadrotor in Mujoco which requires the use of actuators and sensors beyond bodies and geoms.

Letâ€™s start by defining mujoco model. Use the model parameter for naming your model. The rest of the elements will be placed inside this structure.

<mujoco model='quadrotor'>
    <!-- Body -->
</mujoco>

You will only see black background. We can change that by using asset command.

<mujoco model='quadrotor'>
    <asset>
        <texture type="skybox" builtin="gradient" rgb1="1 1 1"
            rgb2=".6 .8 1" width="256" height="256"/>
    </asset>
</mujoco>

Now, letâ€™s create a floor. First we will create a worldbody, which acts as the parent to all others bodies.

<mujoco model='quadrotor'>
    <asset>
        <texture type="skybox" builtin="gradient" rgb1="1 1 1"
            rgb2=".6 .8 1" width="256" height="256"/>
    </asset>
    <worldbody>
        <geom name='floor' type='plane' size='5 5 .1' rgba='1 0 0 1'/>
    </worldbody>
</mujoco>

Geoms are used for collision calculation. The shape is chosen using the type parameter. size gives the dimensions of the geom. You only specify the half values in size. The values are of the form x y z. It spans both positive and negative axis equally. The values 5 2 .1 means 5 in +x and 5 in -x direction. Similar for other axes as well.

Next, we will design the quadrotor. Letâ€™s start by defining the body.

Name Description
body Objects that have inertia and mass but no geometry
geom Used to give shape to bodies
rgba Specify the colour of objects
